ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.1.2_0: At that time King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wanted to rule as sovereign lord over him. He ruled in his own villages.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.1.3_0: And at Campā there was a prominent merchant who had a son called Soṇa Koḷivisa. He had been raised in great comfort
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.1.4_0: and even had hairs growing on the soles of his feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.1.5_0: On one occasion, because of some business, King Bimbisāra had the chiefs of those eighty thousand villages gathered. He then sent a message to Soṇa,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.2_0: “Soṇa, the king wishes to see your feet,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.3_0: but don’t point your feet at the King.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.4_0: If you just sit down cross-legged in front of the King,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.5_0: he’ll be able to see them.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.6_0: And they sent him away on a palanquin.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.7_0: He then went to King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.2.8_0: He saw the Koḷiya Bimbisāra’s feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.3.1_0: Then, after instructing those eighty thousand chiefs in worldly matters, the King dismissed them, saying,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.3.3_0: Now go and visit the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.3.4_0: He will instruct us about the afterlife.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.3.5_0: Those eighty thousand chiefs then went to the Vulture Peak.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.4.1_0: There they approached Venerable Sāgata, who at that time was the Buddha’s attendant.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.4.3_0: “Venerable, these eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.4.5_0: “Well then, please wait here for a moment, while I announce you to the Buddha.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.5.1_0: After looking at those eighty thousand chiefs, he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.5.2_0: “Venerable, these eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.5.3_0: adding, “Sir, please come at your convenience.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.5.4_0: “Well then, Sāgata, please prepare a seat in the shade of the dwelling.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.6.2_0: He took a stool, sunk down in front of the Buddha, and as those eighty thousand chiefs were watching, he once more emerged from that stone slab. He then prepared a seat in the shade of the dwelling,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.6.3_0: Then the Buddha left his dwelling and sat in the shade of the dwelling on the seat spread out.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.7.1_0: Those eighty thousand chiefs approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.7.2_0: But they were preoccupied with Sāgata, not with the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.7.3_0: After reading the minds of those eighty thousand chiefs, the Buddha said to Sāgata,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.7.4_0: “Well then, Sāgata, show us more superhuman abilities, more wonders of supernormal power.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.7.5_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” he rose up into the air, walked back and forth in space, and he stood, sat down, and lay down there. He emitted smoke and fire, and then disappeared.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.8.1_0: After this display of supernormal powers, he bowed down at the feet of the Buddha, and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.8.6_0: Those eighty thousand chiefs thought, “It’s astonishing and amazing
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.8.7_0: that even a disciple should be so powerful and mighty. Imagine what the teacher must be like!” And now they paid attention to the Buddha, not to Sāgata.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.1_0: Having read their minds, the Buddha gave those eighty thousand chiefs a progressive teaching:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.2_0: talk on generosity, talk on morality, talk on heaven; and he revealed the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and the benefit of renunciation.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.3_0: When the Buddha knew that their minds were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.4_0: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.5_0: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.6_0: In the same way, while they were sitting right there, they experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.9.7_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.1_0: They had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; they had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. And they said to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.3_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.4_0: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.5_0: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.6_0: We go for refuge to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.7_0: and to the Dhamma, and to the Community of monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.10.8_0: Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.11.2_0: “As I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.11.3_0: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.11.4_0: Then those eighty thousand chiefs approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.1_0: Soon after they had left, Soṇa approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.2_0: and told him what was happening.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.3_0: “Venerable Sir, the way I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.4_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.5_0: Please give me the going forth.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.6_0: And Soṇa received the going forth and the full ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.12.7_0: Soon after his ordination, while staying in Cool Grove,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.1_0: Their energy was stressed down with energy aroused
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.2_0: His walking-path was soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.3_0: Then, while he was in seclusion, he thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.4_0: “I am one of the Buddha’s most energetic disciples.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.5_0: yet my mind isn’t freed from the corruptions without grasping.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.6_0: And it’s true that my family is wealthy.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.7_0: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.13.8_0: Perhaps I should return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.1_0: Just then the Buddha read Soṇa’s mind.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2_1: so did he vanish from the Vulture Peak and appeared in Cool Wood.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.3_0: Soon afterwards as the Buddha and a number of monks were walking about the dwellings, they came to Soṇa’s walking-path.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.4_0: The Buddha looked at it and asked the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.5_0: “Whose walking-path is this? It’s soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.6_0: And they told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.14.7_0: And because he walked up and down, as if a slaughterhouse.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.1_0: The Buddha then approached Soṇa’s dwelling and sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.2_0: Soṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.3_0: and the Buddha said to him,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.4_0: “Soṇa, when you were in seclusion, didn’t you think,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.5_0: ‘I am one of the Buddha’s most energetic disciples.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.6_0: yet my mind isn’t freed from the corruptions without grasping.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.7_0: And it’s true that my family is wealthy.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.8_0: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.9_0: Perhaps I should return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit?’”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.11_0: “Think about it, Soṇa. When you were previously a householder, weren’t you a skilled lute player?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.15.13_0: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too tight, was it resonant and playable?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.16.1_0: “When your harp’s strings were tuned too slack, was it resonant and playable?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.16.3_0: “But when the strings were neither too tight nor too loose, but set to a balanced tension, was the lute then melodious and easy to play?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.16.5_0: “In the same way, Soṇa, when energy is too forceful it leads to restlessness. When energy is too slack it leads to laziness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.17.1_0: So exert a balanced energy and discover an evenness of the spiritual faculties. And that is where you should take up the meditation object.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3_0: Then the Buddha, having advised and instructed him as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared in front of him.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3_1: so too, the Buddha disappeared from the Vulture Peak and appeared in front of Soṇa.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.18.1_0: After some time, Soṇa exerted a balanced energy, discovered an evenness of the spiritual faculties, and that is where he took up his meditation object.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.18.2_0: He then stayed by himself, secluded, heedful, energetic, and diligent. And in this very life, he soon realized with his own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.18.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.18.4_0: And Venerable Soṇa became one of the perfected.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.19.2_0: “Let me declare perfect insight in the presence of the Buddha.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.19.3_0: He then went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.20.1_0: “Sir, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—is dedicated to sixth.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.20.2_0: to renunciation, seclusion, harmlessness, the end of grasping, the end of craving, and non-confusion.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.21.2_0: ʻNo doubt this venerable is committed to renunciation because of confidence.’ But this is the wrong way to look at it.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.21.3_0: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.22.2_0: ‘Maybe this venerable is dedicated to seclusion because they enjoy possessions, honor, and popularity.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.22.3_0: But this is the wrong way to look at it.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.22.4_0: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.23.2_0: ʻNo doubt this venerable is committed to non-harming because he has fallen back on adhering to conduct and vows as the essence of the spiritual life.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.23.3_0: But this is the wrong way to look at it.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.23.4_0: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.24.1_0: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.24.2_0: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.24.3_0: They’re dedicated to clarity of mind because they’re free of greed, hate, and delusion with the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.25.1_0: When a mendicant’s mind is rightly freed like this, even if compelling sights come into the range of vision they don’t overcome their mind.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.25.2_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.25.3_0: Even if he hears compelling sounds,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.25.7_0: and thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t occupy the mind.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.25.8_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.1_0: It’s just like a granite mountain, a single solid mass without cracks. It doesn’t shake or tremble when powerful rainstorms arrive from any direction.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.2_0: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the west,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.4_0: They couldn’t make it tremor and tremble and quake.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.5_0: The mind of the monk who is fully freed in this way is just like that.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.6_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.7_0: Even if he hears compelling sounds,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.11_0: and thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t occupy the mind.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.26.12_0: The mind remains unaffected. It is steady, imperturbable, observing disappearance.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.1_0: For the one committed to renunciation
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.2_0: And to seclusion of the mind,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.4_0: And to the end of grasping,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.5_0: when you’re dedicated to the ending of craving
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.7_0: and you’ve seen the arising of the senses,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.9_0: For the one who is fully freed,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.17_0: And mental objects, good and bad,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.18_0: Cannot move that kind of person.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.27.20_0: And they observe it as it disappears.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.28.1_0: The Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.28.2_0: “It’s in this way that someone from a good family declares perfect insight. The matter is spoken of, but the person isn’t mentioned.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.28.3_0: And still some foolish men here seem to declare perfect insight just for fun. Afterward they experience distress because of that.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.29.1_0: The Buddha then said to Soṇa,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.29.3_0: I allow you to use sandals with single-layered soles.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.29.4_0: “I’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in such carts. And I’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.29.5_0: Sir, I’ll deliberate lie down on the same poet.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.29.6_0: and now he’s attached to sandals with single-layered soles.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.30.1_0: If you allow them to the Sangha of monks, I too will use them.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.30.2_0: If you don’t allow them to the Sangha of monks, I too will use them.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.30.3_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.30.5_0: And you should not wear sandals with multi-layered soles.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:1.30.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.1.1_0: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six wore entirely blue sandals,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.1.8_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.1.9_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.1.11_0: “You should not wear entirely blue sandals, entirely black sandals,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.1.12_0: entirely yellow, entirely red, entirely magenta, entirely black, entirely orange, or entirely beige.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.1.13_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals with blue straps,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.2_0: yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, and beige straps.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.3_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.4_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6_0: “You should not wear sandals with blue straps,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6_1: yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.2.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals containing leather,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1_1: enclosing the shin and the foot, enclosing the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having straps fastened with ram-horn, having straps fastened with goat-horn, having straps like scorpion claws, sewn with thread like a peacock’s tail-feather, and decorated in various ways.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.5_0: “You should not wear sandals containing leather,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.6_0: enclosing the shin and the foot, enclosing the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having straps fastened with ram-horn, having straps fastened with goat-horn, having straps like scorpion claws, sewn with thread like a peacock’s tail-feather, or decorated in various ways.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.3.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals decorated with lion-skin,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.1_1: tiger-skin, leopard-skin, deer-skin, otter-skin, cat-skin, squirrel-skin, and bat-skin.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.5_0: “You should not wear sandals decorated with lion-skin,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.6_0: tiger-skin, leopard-skin, deer-skin, otter-skin, cat-skin, squirrel-skin, or bat-skin.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:2.4.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.1.0_0: The allowance for second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.1.1_0: After robing up one morning, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and entered Rājagaha for almsfood together with an attendant monk.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.1.2_0: As he was following behind the Buddha, that monk was limping.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.1.3_0: A certain lay follower wearing sandals with multi-layered soles saw the Buddha coming.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4_0: Having seen his sandals, he went to the Fortunate One,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he went to that monk,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.2.4_0: “Thanks, but the Buddha has prohibited sandals with multi-layered soles.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.2.6_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.2.7_0: “I allow second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.2.8_0: But you should not wear new sandals with multi-layered soles.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:3.2.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.1.1_0: On one occasion the Buddha walked up and down outside without sandals.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.1.3_0: The senior monks followed his example,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.1.4_0: The monks from the group of six walked up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.1.5_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.1.6_0: “How can the monks from the group of six walk up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.2.1_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.2.2_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.2.5_0: “... How can those foolish men walk up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.2.6_0: Even the white-clothed laypeople can respect for the white-clothed laypeople who is respected and reverence for the teacher, the restor, and the way will live on.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.1_0: Having gone forth on this well-proclaimed spiritual path, will you look after your preceptors, preceptors, or teachers?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.2_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.4_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.5_0: “You should not walk up and down with sandals when your teachers, your preceptors, or those of equivalent standing do it without.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.7_0: And you should not wear sandals within a monastery.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:4.3.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.1.1_0: Soon afterwards a certain monk was afflicted with corns on his feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.1.2_0: The monks had to hold him while he urinated and defecated.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.1.3_0: Just then as the Buddha was walking about the dwellings, he saw this. He approached those monks and said to them,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.2.2_0: “He has corns on his feet, Sir.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.2.3_0: That’s why we do this for him.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.2.4_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:5.2.5_0: “For anyone whose feet are suffering, foot-stands for fruit, or foot-stands for fruit.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.1.1_0: The monks used beds and benches with dirty feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.1.2_0: Their robes and the furniture became dirty.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.1.4_0: “When you know that you are about to use a bed or bench, I allow you to wear sandals.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.2.1_0: When monks were going to the observance hall or a meeting in the dark of night, they stepped on stumps and thorns, and eventually stumps.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.2.1_1: and as a result their feet hurt.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.2.3_0: “I allow you to wear sandals within a monastery, and also to use a torch, a lamp, and a walking stick.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.3.1_0: At that time, when the monks from the group of six were getting up early in the morning, they made a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of unworthy talk, such as
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.3.2_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.3.3_0: and stepped off a chopping sound,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.1_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.2_0: “How can the monks from the group of six act like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.3_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers ...
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.4_0: They might engage in malicious talebearing for continued existence, while the mendicants will not start their immersion.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.5_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.6_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.7_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers ...
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.8_0: They engaged in malicious talebearing for continued existence, and they don’t get immersion.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.9_0: “It’s true, Sir.” ... and the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.11_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:6.4.13_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.1_0: After staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Benares.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.2_0: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Benares,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.3_0: he stayed in the deer park at Isipatana.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.5_0: the Buddha had prohibited wooden shoes,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.6_0: cuttings made from palm leaves and wear shoes made of palm leaves,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.7_0: when those young palm trees wither as a consequence?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.8_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.9_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.10_0: when those young palm trees wither as a consequence?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.1.11_0: They are harming life with one sense faculty.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.1_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.2_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.3_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.4_0: when those young palm trees cling to me?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.7_0: “... How can those foolish men have cuttings made from young palm trees and wear shoes made of palm leaves,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.8_0: when those young palm trees wither as a consequence?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.10_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.12_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.13_0: “You should not wear shoes made of palm leaves.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.2.14_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.2_0: the Buddha had prohibited shoes made of palm leaves,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.3_0: the monks from the group of six had cuttings made from young bamboo plants and wore shoes made of bamboo leaves.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.5_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.6_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.8_0: They are harming life with one sense faculty.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.9_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.10_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.12_0: And you should not wear shoes made of bamboo leaves.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:7.3.13_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.1.1_0: After staying at Benares for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Bhaddiya.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.1.3_0: he stayed in the Jātiyā Grove.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.1.4_0: At that time the monks in Bhaddiya were fond of various kinds of nice shoes. They made shoes of grass, fishtail-palm leaves, and wool, and they had them made. As a consequence, they neglected recitation, questioning, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.1_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.2_0: “How can those monks in Bhaddiya be fond of various kinds of nice shoes? They are fond of various kinds of nice shoes, and chopping animals, and overlying grass? Ambalans, under the infatuated, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.3_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.4_0: “Is it true, monks, that the monks in Bhaddiya do this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.5_0: and neglect recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.8_0: “... How can those foolish men be fond of various kinds of nice shoes ...
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.2.9_0: and neglect recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.1_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.3_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.4_0: “You should not wear straw sandals, chopping blocks, grass, reeds, bamboo leaves, wood-appoints, fruits, metal leaves, or wear cotton, or wear cotton.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.5_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.6_0: But you should not wear shoes made from pillows.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.8_0: I allow three kinds of foot-stands that are fixed in place and immobile:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:8.3.9_0: foot-stands for defecating, foot-stands for urinating, foot-stands for restroom rinsing.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.1.1_0: After staying at Bhaddiya for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.1.3_0: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.1.4_0: At this time, when cattle were crossing the Aciravatī river, the monks from the group of six would grab them by the horns, the ears, the neck, and the tail, and they mounted their backs, and motivated by lust, they touched their genitals. They even killed a calf by submerging it.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.2.1_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.2.2_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.2.3_0: They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!” ...
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.2.4_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.2.5_0: They then told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned them:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.1_0: “It’s true, Sir.” ... and the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.3_0: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.4_0: “You should not grab cattle by the horns, the ears, the neck, or the tail, and you should not mount their backs.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.5_0: If you do mount their backs, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.6_0: And you should not touch their genitals motivated by lust.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.7_0: If you do, you commit a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.8_0: And you should not kill a calf.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.3.9_0: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.4.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six traveled in vehicles, sometimes pulled by women with men inside, at other times pulled by men with women inside.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.4.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.4.3_0: “It’s as if they’re at the Ganges festival.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.4.5_0: “You should not travel in a vehicle.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:9.4.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.1.1_0: Soon afterwards a certain monk was walking through the Kosalan country on his way to Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.1.2_0: He stepped off the path and sat down at the foot of a tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.1.5_0: “I’m going to Sāvatthī to visit the Buddha.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.2.4_0: “Thanks, but the Buddha has prohibited us from traveling in vehicles.” And being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.2.5_0: He then went to Sāvatthī and told the monks what had happened,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.2.6_0: They in turn told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.2.7_0: “I allow a vehicle for one who is sick.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.3.2_0: “A vehicle pulled by women or by men?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.3.4_0: “I allow a rickshaw pulled by men.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.3.5_0: Soon afterwards a certain monk was even more uncomfortable when jolted around in a vehicle.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.3.7_0: “I allow a palanquin and a litter.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.4.0_0: The prohibition against high and luxurious resting places
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.4.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six used high and luxurious resting places, such as:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.4.2_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a quilt filled with cotton down, a woolen rug decorated with the images of wild animals, a woolen rug with long flece on one side, a woolen rug with long flece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent rug made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a bed with a canopy, a bed
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.4.3_0: People who were walking about the dwellings saw this, and they complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.4.4_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.5.1_0: “You should not use high and luxurious resting places, such as:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.5.2_0: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a quilt filled with cotton down, a woolen rug decorated with the images of wild animals, a woolen rug with long flece on one side, a woolen rug with long flece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent sheet made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a bed with a canopy, a bed
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.5.3_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.2_0: that the Buddha had prohibited luxurious resting places,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.3_0: they used luxurious skins: lion skins, tiger skins, and leopard skins.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.4_0: The beds were broken, spots, weather-damaged, cutting off, and outside.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.5_0: People who were walking about the dwellings saw this, and they complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.6_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.8_0: “You should not use luxurious skins: lion skins, tiger skins, or leopard skins.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.6.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.7.2_0: the Buddha had prohibited luxurious skins,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.7.4_0: The beds were broken, spots, weather-damaged, cutting off, and outside.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.7.5_0: At this time a certain bad monk was associating with the family of a bad lay follower.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.7.6_0: One morning that monk robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to that lay follower’s house, where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.7.7_0: That lay follower approached the monk, bowed, and sat down.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.1_0: At that time that lay follower had a beautiful young calf with variegated hide, just like a young leopard.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.2_0: The bad monk stared at that calf
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.3_0: and the lay follower asked him why.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.4_0: “Sir, why are you able to start these calves?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.5_0: He replied, “I want the skin of that calf.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.6_0: The bad lay follower then slaughtered the calf, skinned it, and gave the skin to the bad monk.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.8.7_0: The monk hid the skin under his upper robe and left.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.1_0: The mother-cow, longing for her calf, followed behind him.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.4_0: he replied he did not know.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.5_0: But his upper robe was smeared with blood
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.8_0: When he had told them what had happened,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.9_0: they said, “So did you encourage someone to kill?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.11_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.9.12_0: “How can a monk encourage someone to kill? Hasn’t the Buddha in many ways criticized killing and praised the abstention from killing?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.1_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned that bad monk:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.2_0: “Is it true, monk, that you encouraged someone to kill?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.3_0: “It’s true, Sir.” ... and the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.4_0: “Foolish man, how can you encourage someone to kill? Haven’t I in many ways criticized killing and praised the abstention from killing?
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.5_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.6_0: after criticizing them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.8_0: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.9_0: And you should not use cattle hide.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.10_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.11_0: And you should not use any kind of skin.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:10.10.12_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:11.1.1_0: At that time people’s beds and benches were upholstered and covered with skin.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:11.1.2_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit on them.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:11.1.4_0: “I allow you to sit down on what belongs to householders, but not to lie down on it.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:11.1.5_0: But then the dwellings were held together by straps of leather.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:11.1.6_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit on them.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:11.1.8_0: “I allow you to sit down against a mere binding made of skin.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six entered the villages without sandals.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.2_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.5_0: “You should not enter the village wearing sandals.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.7_0: Soon afterwards a certain sick monk was not able to enter the village without his sandals.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:12.1.9_0: “I allow sick monks to enter the village while wearing sandals.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in Avantī on Papataka Hill at Kuraraghara.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.1.2_0: And the layman Soṇa of the pointy ears was Mahākaccānas attendant.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.1.3_0: On one occasion Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.1.5_0: “Venerable, the way I understand your teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.1.6_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.1.7_0: Please give me the going forth.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.1_0: “It’s difficult, Soṇa, to live the spiritual life all one’s life, eating one meal a day and sleeping by oneself.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.2_0: So follow the instruction of the Buddhas while remaining as a householder, and at suitable times you may eat one meal a day, sleep by yourself, and practice celibacy.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.3_0: As a result, Soṇa’s intention to go forth died down.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.4_0: A second time Soṇa asked Mahākaccāna for the going forth, but got the same response.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.5_0: For a third time Soṇa went up to Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.7_0: “Venerable, the way I understand your teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.8_0: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.9_0: Please give me the going forth.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.11_0: At that time in the southern region of Avantī, there were few monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.2.12_0: Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was Mahākaccāna able to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give the full ordination to Venerable Soṇa.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.3.0_0: The making known of the five favors for Mahākaccāna
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.3.1_0: While he was in seclusion after completing the rainy-season residence, Soṇa thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.3.2_0: “I’ve heard that the Buddha is like this and like that, but I haven’t seen this for myself. If my preceptor allows me, I shall go and visit the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.3.3_0: When he had come out from seclusion, Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.4.2_0: “Just now, Sir, while I was in seclusion, I thought,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.4.3_0: ‘I’ve heard that the Buddha is like this and like that, but I haven’t seen this for myself. If my preceptor allows me, I shall go and visit the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.4.4_0: “Sir, I’d go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha! If my preceptor allows me.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.4.6_0: Please go and visit the Buddha, the perfected and fully awakened one.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.5.1_0: You will see him—pleasing to the eye and inspiring confidence; peaceful in mind and faculties; attained to the supreme subduing and calm; tamed, guarded, and restrained in his sense faculties; a great being.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.5.2_0: Then, Soṇa, in my name, pay respect with your head at the Buddha’s feet and say, ʻ
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.5.3_0: ‘My preceptor Po at the feet of the Buddha, bows with his head to your feet.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.5.5_0: ʻIn the southern region of Avantī, Sir, there are few monks. Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was it possible to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give me the full ordination.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.5.6_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow a smaller group of monks to give the full ordination in Avantī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.1_0: In Avantī the ground is dark and hard, made rough by the hooves of cattle.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.2_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sandals with multi-layered soles in Avantī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.3_0: In Avantī people value bathing and cleanliness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.4_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow unrestricted bathing in Avantī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.5_0: In Avantī sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.6_0: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.7_0: In the same way, In the southern region, deer-skin, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.6.8_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins as rugs in Avantī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.7.1_0: At present people give robes to monks who are outside the monastic boundary, saying,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.7.3_0: When those monks return to the monastery, they are told,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.7.4_0: “Such-and-such people have given you a robe.” But being afraid of wrongdoing, they don’t accept, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.7.5_0: “We might commit an offense entailing relinquishment.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.7.6_0: Hopefully the Buddha will tell him every robes.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.7.8_0: Then Soṇa got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Mahākaccāna, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.8.1_0: When he eventually arrived at Sāvatthī, he went to the Buddha in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery. He bowed to the Buddha and sat down.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.8.5_0: “When the Buddha says this, it means he wishes to stay in the same dwelling as Venerable Soṇa.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.8.6_0: And he prepared a resting place for Soṇa in the Buddha’s dwelling.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.1_0: Then, after spending much of the night outside, the Buddha entered the dwelling,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.3_0: Rising early in the morning, the Buddha said to Soṇa,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.4_0: “May you be inspired to speak about the Dhamma, monk.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.6_0: When he was finished, the Buddha said,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.8_0: You have learned the Chapter Eights well; you have remembered it well.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.9_0: And you have a good voice—it’s clear, articulate, and gets the meaning across.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.9.10_0: How long have you been a monk?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.10.1_0: “Why did it take you so long to go forth?”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.10.2_0: “I have long seen the danger in worldly pleasures. Still, because household life is crowded and very busy, I was not able to leave.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.10.3_0: Seeing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha exclaimed an inspired utterance:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.10.5_0: I understood the reality without attachments.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.10.6_0: The Noble One does not delight in bad deeds,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.10.7_0: In the bad, the pure one doesn’t delight.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.2_0: “The Buddha approves of me. This is the time to bring up what my preceptor said.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.3_0: He got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, bowed down at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.4_0: “Sir, my preceptor bows with his head to the Buddha’s feet. And he says,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.5_0: Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, the Buddha would allow a Order of monks to give me the full ordination and little full ordination in Avantī. Only the Buddha would allow them to give me the full ordination to peace.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.6_0: In Avantī the ground is dark and hard, made rough by the hooves of cattle.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.7_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sandals with multi-layered soles in Avantī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.8_0: In Avantī people value bathing and cleanliness. Hopefully, water, and stars—the Buddha will allow tooth clean and water.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.9_0: In Avantī sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.10_0: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.11_0: In the same way, In the southern region, deer-skin, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.12_0: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins as rugs in Avantī.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.13_0: At present people give robes to monks who are outside the monastic boundary, saying,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.15_0: When those monks return to the monastery, they are told,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.16_0: ‘Such-and-such people have given you a robe.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.17_0: They were afraid of wrongdoing and did not accept it:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.18_0: ‘We might commit an offense entailing relinquishment.’
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.19_0: Hopefully the Buddha will describe the end.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.20_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.21_0: “In the southern region of Avantī there are few monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.11.22_0: In all outlying countries, I allow you to give the full ordination to someone else.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.1_0: In this case, there are these last countries:
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.2_0: In the eastern direction there is a town called _Gajaṅgala_, with another town called _Mahāsālā_ on the other side of it. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.3_0: In the south-eastern direction there is a river called _Sallavatī_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.4_0: In the southern direction there is a town called _Setakaṇṇika_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.5_0: In the western direction there is a brahmin named Thūṇa. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.6_0: In the northern direction there is a mountain called _Usīraddhaja_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.12.7_0: In the borderlands, I allow you to receive the full ordination in the border country.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.1_0: In Avantī the ground is dark and hard, made rough by the hooves of cattle.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.2_0: In all outlying countries, I allow sandals with multi-layered soles.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.3_0: In Avantī people value bathing and cleanliness.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.4_0: In all outlying countries, I allow unrestricted bathing.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.5_0: In Avantī sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.6_0: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.7_0: In the same way, when in Avantī sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.8_0: In all outlying countries, I allow rugs of sheep-skin, goat-skin, and deer-skin.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.9_0: And it may happen that people give robes to monks who are outside the monastic boundary, saying, ʻ
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.11_0: I allow you to accept it and not start counting the days until you have the robe in your hand.”
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.12_0: The fifth chapter on skins is finished.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.14_0: King Soṇa, the king of Magadha,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.16_0: he has gone to the Vulture’s Peak.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.29_0: Kāḷily examines the meaning of Kāḷigodhā’s teeth
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.32_0: And a palm tree that’s plucked out,
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.48_0: and he taught the following method of the deathless.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.52_0: In this chapter there are sixty-three topics.
ai-pli-tv-kd5:13.13.53_0: The chapter on skins is finished.
